channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Debate Over Identity and Race Asks, Are African-Americans ‘Black’ or ‘black’?
item.description: The push to capitalize black to refer to African-Americans is far more than a typographical change.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prominence of the Black Lives Matter movement has helped reignite the debate over the capitalization of the word black. Above, protests continued last week following the killing by the police of Rayshard Brooks in Atlanta.

item.title: Many Latinos Couldn’t Stay Home. Now Covid Cases Are Soaring in their Communities.
item.description: Rates of coronavirus infection among Latinos have risen rapidly across the United States.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Thomas Fuller, Anjali Singhvi and Juliette Love
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Shawn Hubler/The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re the ones who are out in the work force,” said Cynthia Orozco, a 20-year-old high school tutor and civil engineering major at California State University, Fresno, who contracted the virus along with her mother, Graciela Ramirez, a machine operator at Ruiz Foods in Dinuba, Calif.

item.title: As Virus Surges, Younger People Account for ‘Disturbing’ Number of Cases
item.description: People in their 20s, 30s and 40s account for a growing proportion of the cases in many places, raising fears that asymptomatic young people are helping to fuel the virus’s spread.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swimmers at the beach on Thursday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The median age of Floridians testing positive for the coronavirus has dropped from 65 in March to 35 now, officials said.

item.title: Texas Governor Greg Abbott Pauses Reopening
item.description: A growing number of states are pausing plans to reopen, amid rising case counts. But Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said shutting back down was the “last thing we want to do.”
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asia Anderson, 25, monitors the line at a drive-through coronavirus testing site at United Memorial Medical Center in Houston.

item.title: ‘PizzaGate’ Conspiracy Theory Thrives Anew in the TikTok Era
item.description: The false theory targeting Democrats, now fueled by QAnon and teenagers on TikTok, is entangling new targets like Justin Bieber.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hateful comments have surged on the social media pages of Comet Ping Pong, a pizza parlor in Washington that is at the center of the debunked PizzaGate conspiracy theory.

item.title: On Coronavirus, Americans Still Trust the Experts
item.description: But that trust may be tested in the months ahead.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Sarah Silbiger
item.media:description: Trust in Dr. Anthony Fauci is generally high, but there’s a partisan split, with 51 percent of Republicans trusting him compared with 81 percent of Democrats who do.

item.title: Black Trans Women Seek More Space in the Movement They Helped Start
item.description: At no point have black trans people shared fully in the gains of the L.G.B.T.Q. or racial justice movements. This may be changing.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz and Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Gioncarlo Valentine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nala Toussaint, a trans activist and organizer.

item.title: ‘A True Disappointment’: How It Feels When Your First Pride Parade Is Canceled
item.description: The coronavirus has led to the canceling of the big gatherings that have defined Pride. For many, that means missing out, for now, on an important moment of visibility and acceptance.
item.dc:creator: Pierre-Antoine Louis
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pride March in New York last year celebrated the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall protests.

item.title: A Reckoning With Race to Ensure Diversity for America’s Face Abroad
item.description: The national conversation about discrimination is overdue at the State Department, according to those who have been disparaged in a culture that favors “pale, male and Yale” diplomats.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: John IV Branch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tianna Spears said she left the State Department after an embassy medical official told her that she had developed anxiety, depression and post-traumatic stress disorder.

item.title: How Trump and the Black Lives Matter Movement Changed White Voters’ Minds
item.description: A majority of American voters support demonstrations on police brutality, and many see the president as ill-equipped on racial justice.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Diana Zeyneb Alhindawi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters marched through Columbus Circle in Manhattan on Juneteenth.

item.title: The Black Officer Who Detained George Floyd Had Pledged to Fix the Police
item.description: Alex Kueng is one of four former officers accused of crimes in the killing of Mr. Floyd, which happened on his third shift. His decision to join the force had frayed friendships.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Hennepin County Sheriff's Office, via Reuters

item.title: Biden Still Wants to Close Guantánamo Prison
item.description: The Obama administration ran into a wall of political opposition when it tried. The former vice president rarely brings up the topic and has yet to draw up a strategy but says he shares the goal.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. rarely, if ever, brings up the topic of closing down Guantánamo Bay’s prison.

item.title: Obamacare Faces Unprecedented Test as Economy Sinks
item.description: The battles over the health law have played out during a decade of continuous economic growth. How it performs as a safety net now may help determine its future.
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough and Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Jacob Biba for The New York Times
item.media:description: Morgan Childers, of Cullowhee, N.C., lost her employer-based insurance because of the pandemic, and lives with an autoimmune disorder whose monthly costs are in the thousands without insurance.

item.title: Trump Issues Executive Order Targeting Vandalism Against Monuments
item.description: The order also threatens to withhold funding from local governments that fail to protect their own statues from vandals.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters near the White House failed this week to topple a statue of Andrew Jackson in Lafayette Square.

item.title: 7 Killed in Crash in El Paso After Border Patrol Tried to Stop Car
item.description: The vehicle, which was carrying 10 people, had been pursued before it crashed into a semitrailer on private property, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Briana Sanchez/The El Paso Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Three people were seriously injured in the crash.

item.title: Leaders Re-examine U.S. Reopenings as Coronavirus Cases Hit Another Record
item.description: Officials nationwide were rethinking their efforts to slow the virus, which the nation’s top infectious disease expert said were “not working.”
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Sarah Mervosh and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tasia Markantonis, the manager of West Alabama Ice House in Houston, closed a customer’s tab at noon Friday, when Texas bars had to close again because of the coronavirus.

item.title: 3 Die in New Mexico After Drinking Hand Sanitizer, Officials Say
item.description: A spokesman for the state’s Health Department said the cases were related to alcoholism.
item.dc:creator: Marie Fazio
item.media:credit: Seth Wenig/Associated Press
item.media:description: Hand sanitizer is sometimes consumed for its high alcohol content.

item.title: Justice Dept. to Take Aim at Antigovernment Extremists
item.description: The attorney general said that extremists on the far right and left who committed acts of violence during protests against police brutality will be treated like organized crime or terrorists.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Shawn Thew/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Attorney General William Barr, center, directed Justice Department officials to root out antigovernment extremism.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Dr. Anthony Fauci warned that outbreaks in the South and West are threatening to engulf the country.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Fact Checking Mike Pence on the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The vice president falsely claimed that increased testing “is generating” more cases, among other exaggerations and inaccurate claims.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence went beyond spin in the first coronavirus task force briefing in many weeks.

item.title: New Numbers Showing Coronavirus Spread Intrude on a White House in Denial
item.description: Both President Trump and Vice President Pence seem oblivious to the new chapter in the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump made no mention on Friday, during a business meeting at the White House, of the increase in Covid-19 cases around the country.

item.title: After Functioning for 28 Days, U.S. Election Regulator Will Be Powerless Again
item.description: A member of the Federal Election Commission said Friday that she was resigning, just weeks after a new member had joined the agency and restored its quorum.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images
item.media:description: Caroline C. Hunter’s departure will leave the Federal Election Commission with just three of six members.

item.title: Many Students Will Be in Classrooms Only Part of the Week This Fall
item.description: Some American school districts are beginning to announce hybrid schedules that include a mix of online and in-school learning, presenting a difficult challenge for working parents.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Julio Cortez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Cherye Graves’s fourth-grade classroom at Eastside Elementary in Clinton, Miss., after students were forced to stay home in March during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Who Gets Lifesaving Care? Tennessee Changes Rules After Federal Complaint
item.description: Disability rights groups said state guidelines on who would, and who wouldn’t, receive coronavirus treatment during a shortage was discriminatory.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Fink
item.media:credit: Mark Humphrey/Associated Press
item.media:description: A patient was removed in March from a long-term care facility in Gallatin, Tenn., where many fell ill with Covid-19.

item.title: Appeals Court Rejects Trump’s Diversion of Military Funds for Border Wall
item.description: An appeals court ruled that President Trump illegally diverted funding for his border wall without congressional approval, likely sending the issue to the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump visiting a section of the border wall on Tuesday in San Luis, Ariz.

item.title: Bunn-O-Matic Shooting: 2 Dead, 1 Critically Wounded, Officials Say
item.description: The gunman was later found dead and the authorities were investigating a motive for the attack at the Bunn-O-Matic warehouse in Springfield, Ill.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele
item.media:credit: Justin L. Fowler/The State Journal-Register, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The victims were all workers at the company and those killed were white men, one in his mid-20s and another in his 60s, officials said.

item.title: Thomas Blanton, Who Bombed a Birmingham Church, Dies at 82
item.description: He was the last survivor of three Klansmen who were convicted, years later, in the killing four black girls in 1963, a case that was a turning point in the civil rights struggle.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Mr. Blanton after he was convicted on four counts of murder in 2001. He was give four consecutive life sentences and died in prison.

item.title: Supreme Court Turns Down Request to Allow All Texans to Vote by Mail
item.description: Democrats in the state had urged the justices to reinstate a federal trial judge’s order based on the 26th Amendment, which bars voting discrimination based on age.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An election clerk outside a polling place in Austin, Texas, before a primary election in March.

item.title: ‘TikTok Grandma’ Who Helped Tank Trump Rally Now Works for Biden
item.description: Mary Jo Laupp, who made a viral TikTok video that disrupted a Trump campaign event, plans to create a “political hype house” to support Joe Biden.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Mary Jo Laupp, whose TikTok video urging people to reserve seats but not show up at a Trump rally went viral.

item.title: House Fails to Override Trump’s Veto Limiting Student Loan Debt Relief
item.description: Stringent new rules by Education Secretary Betsy DeVos are set to take effect on July 1 after the attempt to reverse them was defeated.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos’s changes raised the bar for borrower relief claims, requiring applicants to individually prove that a school knowingly misled them.

item.title: House Approves D.C. Statehood in Historic Vote
item.description: It is the first time a chamber of Congress has approved establishing the nation’s capital as the 51st state. The measure is all but certain to die in the Republican-led Senate.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi during a news conference on Thursday about statehood for the District of Columbia.

item.title: Iraq Raids Iranian-Backed Militia Accused of Attacking U.S. Forces
item.description: Iraqi forces detained 14 members of the group, Khataib Hezbollah, to send a message that “no one is above the law.”
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers surveying the launch site of a rocket attack in January that killed an American contractor on a military base near Kirkuk. The United States blamed the Khataib Hezbollah militia for the attack.

item.title: Russia Secretly Offered Afghan Militants Bounties to Kill U.S. Troops, Intelligence Says
item.description: The Trump administration has been deliberating for months about what to do about a stunning intelligence assessment.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: American troops in Afghanistan have been the target of some Taliban operations backed by Russia, intelligence officials found.

item.title: Going Up? Not So Fast: Strict New Rules to Govern Elevator Culture
item.description: Small, crowded, enclosed spaces are petri dishes for the coronavirus. But in urban office buildings, elevators are a necessity, so companies are wrestling with how to make them safer.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two employees of Boston Properties demonstrated proper safe distancing in an elevator at the Prudential Center in Boston.

item.title: ‘Through Art, I Hope That We Can Make One Tulsa’
item.description: Talking with two organizers of the movement to reclaim the long-ignored history of Black Wall Street and the Greenwood district’s achievements.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Chris Creese for The New York Times
item.media:description: Quraysh Ali Lansana, left, a poet and educator, and Jerica Wortham, project manager of the Greenwood Art Project, are among those trying to make sure the history of Tulsa, Okla., and Black Wall Street isn’t lost.

item.title: YouTube Personality Jenna Marbles Apologizes for Blackface Video
item.description: Jenna Mourey said she was ending her channel, which has more than 20 million subscribers, because of videos from 2011 of her impersonating Nicki Minaj and rapping lyrics about Asians.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Taylor Lorenz
item.media:credit: Stephanie Diani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The YouTube personality Jenna Mourey has been making videos for over a decade under the name Jenna Marbles. She apologized for several videos Thursday.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Valerie Solanas, Radical Feminist Who Shot Andy Warhol
item.description: She made daring arguments in “SCUM Manifesto,” her case for a world without men. But her legacy as a writer and thinker was overshadowed by one violent act.
item.dc:creator: Bonnie Wertheim
item.media:credit: Fred W. McDarrah/Getty Images
item.media:description: Valerie Solanas in the offices of The Village Voice in 1967, the year she published “SCUM Manifesto,” which was, in part, a call to arms for the coalition she was forming, the Society for Cutting Up Men.

item.title: How Cities Are Trying to Avert Gridlock After Coronavirus Lockdowns
item.description: Officials are trying to prevent a return to urban gridlock and pollution as residents begin to travel again.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Kham/Reuters
item.media:description: Rush hour in Hanoi, Vietnam, last month as the country relaxed its nationwide lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus Face Shields vs. Face Masks: Which Is Better?
item.description: There are benefits to wearing face shields, but experts say there are limits to the amount of protection they can offer.
item.dc:creator: Marie Tae McDermott
item.media:credit: Robyn Beck/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Face shields are commonly used by front-line health workers, but more people are looking at face shields as an added layer of protection.

item.title: How Progressive Candidates of Color Are Building Winning Coalitions
item.description: Candidates like Charles Booker and Jamaal Bowman are bringing together liberal white voters and voters of color, a dynamic seen this week in races in Kentucky and New York.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Pat Mcdonogh/Louisville Courier Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Charles Booker, a Democratic Senate candidate in Kentucky, prepared to vote at the Kentucky Expo Center in Louisville.

item.title: A Step Toward 51
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: J. David Ake/Associated Press
item.media:description: Washington at daybreak.
